docs.abstract: Xiyun Yang reviews some government-run restaurants in Beijing that serve authentic regional dishes; photo (M)
docs.snippet: Each region of China has an outpost in the capital, offering some of the best regional cuisine in the country.
docs.lead_paragraph: TWO THOUSAND miles away from Yunnan and its sour papaya fish stews, Wang Li has driven half an hour with her family to Yunteng Shifu, which she considers the most authentic Yunnan restaurant in Beijing. ''The best thing about Beijing is its many provincial bureau restaurants,'' said Ms. Wang, 55, a retired doctor. ''Stay in one place, eat from all over!''

headline.main: Room to Live and Love in China's Cities

docs.snippet: Chinese lesbians are enjoying the freedom brought by urban anonymity and profound social change — but it is a freedom that exists in a gray area, and interest in legal rights is growing.
docs.lead_paragraph: BEIJING -- Shortly after they met, Wu Zheng shocked her girlfriend, Charlene Lee, by kissing her on a Beijing street. ''I said, 'What, you do that here?' I'm from Singapore, and we're conservative. There is that constant fear,'' recalled Ms. Lee, 30.

docs.abstract: Back streets of Beijing offer a truly ancient feel for the traveler discovering the Yonghegong area, a maze of alleys branching out from the 17th-century Lama, or Yonghe, Temple; over past year, combined cafe-boutiques and restaurants with stone courtyards have opened along the strees around the lamasery; photos (M)
docs.snippet: NOWHERE does Beijing feel more ancient than in its alleyways, or hutongs, where the bell chimes of passing bikes keep pedestrians on their toes amid single-story, slate-gray dwellings. These days, there's no better place to get lost in Beijing's back
docs.lead_paragraph: NOWHERE does Beijing feel more ancient than in its alleyways, or hutongs, where the bell chimes of passing bikes keep pedestrians on their toes amid single-story, slate-gray dwellings. These days, there's no better place to get lost in Beijing's back streets than the Yonghegong area, a maze of alleys branching out from the 17th-century Lama, or Yonghe, Temple, a popular tourist spot and one of the city's best-known places of worship. Over the past year, combined cafe-boutiques and restaurants with stone courtyards have opened along the streets around the lamasery. In a city full of high-rise malls, these new spots set themselves apart simply by keeping things quaint: the bars are tiny, pet cats laze about in the cafes, and one fashion designer hands out free brownies on the weekend. COLLEEN KINDER

docs.snippet: In a maze of alleys branching out from the 17th-century Lama, or Yonghe, Temple are new cafes and boutiques.
docs.lead_paragraph: In a maze of alleys branching out from the 17th-century Lama, or Yonghe, Temple are new cafes and boutiques.

docs.abstract: There was a bit of anticipation about whether Mitt Romney and Jon Huntsman would interact at the Independence Day parade here in Amherst, N.H.

headline.main: Mr. Romney, Say Hello to Mr. Huntsman

docs.snippet: There was a bit of anticipation about whether Mitt Romney and Jon Huntsman would interact at the Independence Day parade here in Amherst, N.H.
docs.lead_paragraph: AMHERST, N.H. -- There was a bit of anticipation about whether Mitt Romney and Jon Huntsman would interact at the Independence Day parade here in Amherst -- at least as much anticipation as there can be for a parade route interaction. (Let's face it, it's a slow holiday weekend and the political press can get hungry for drama.)

docs.abstract: Adm Mike Mullen, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, meets with his Chinese counterpart, Gen Chen Bingde, and other senior Chinese officials in sign of a revival in the relationship between the two militaries; photo (M)

headline.main: Joint Chiefs Chairman Meets With Chinese Counterpart

keywords.name: subject
keywords.value: UNITED STATES DEFENSE AND MILITARY FORCES

docs.snippet: The United States’ top military officer met with Chinese officials in Beijing, the first such trip in more than four years.
docs.lead_paragraph: BEIJING -- The United States' top military officer met with Chinese officials in Beijing on Sunday, in the first such trip in more than four years and a sign of revival in what has for years been a stagnant military relationship between the two powers. The chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, Adm. Mike Mullen, held talks with his Chinese counterpart, Gen. Chen Bingde, the chief of the general staff of the People's Liberation Army, and senior Chinese government officials. Admiral Mullen's visit follows a similar trip by General Chen to the United States in May.

docs.abstract: Nicolai Ouroussoff reviews the CCTV Headquarters building in Beijing, China, designed by Rem Koolhaas; photo (M)
docs.snippet: BEIJING -- Aside from the new World Trade Center, it's hard to think of a more contentious architectural project in the last few years than the CCTV building, the headquarters of China Central Television here.      After Rem Koolhaas, the project's a
docs.lead_paragraph: BEIJING -- Aside from the new World Trade Center, it's hard to think of a more contentious architectural project in the last few years than the CCTV building, the headquarters of China Central Television here. After Rem Koolhaas, the project's architect, unveiled the design in 2003 he was pilloried by Western journalists for glorifying a propaganda organ of the Chinese government. Several years later a fire at the site nearly burned down a neighboring building, also designed by Mr. Koolhaas, landing the director of the project and 19 others in prison for negligence and significantly delaying construction.

docs.snippet: Rem Koolhaas’s CCTV building in Beijing, headquarters of China Central Television, has a beguiling and powerful design and is a metaphor for a country racing headlong into the future.
docs.lead_paragraph: BEIJING -- Aside from the new World Trade Center, it's hard to think of a more contentious architectural project in the last few years than the CCTV building, the headquarters of China Central Television here. After Rem Koolhaas, the project's architect -- along with his former Beijing partner, Ole Scheeren -- unveiled the design in 2003 he was pilloried by Western journalists for glorifying a propaganda organ of the Chinese government. Several years later a fire at the site nearly burned down a neighboring building, also designed by Mr. Koolhaas, landing the director of the project and 19 others in prison for negligence and significantly delaying construction.

headline.main: Chinese Opera Gets a Modern Edge

docs.snippet: Efforts to save a 300-year-old art form include government investing in new productions of classic works.
docs.lead_paragraph: HONG KONG -- The Sunbeam Theatre, the last dedicated Cantonese opera house on Hong Kong Island, stands on a crammed neon-lighted corner, decorated with Christmas lights and posters of its elaborately made-up stars. Its 400 annual shows are often sold out, mostly to middle-aged women who know the ancient art form's stories by heart. Singers in hand-embroidered silk costumes play the characters of Chinese legend: emperors and warlords, wily bandits and maidens in distress. Gongs and cymbals clang, sword fights break out, and the odd acrobat somersaults across the stage.

docs.abstract: Apple's Chinese outlets, two in Beijing and two in Shanghai, are the most heavily trafficked of its stores in the world, and generate the most revenue; analysts say few global brands have achieved such a feat in China; Apple's push shows depth of fast-growing upper middle class there; photo (M)

headline.main: In China, Apple Finds Market's Sweet Spot

docs.snippet: Must-have gadgets are causing a stir, with stores packed and inventory sparse.

byline.original: By DAVID BARBOZA; Gu Jinglu contributed research in Shanghai

docs.lead_paragraph: SHANGHAI -- A year after opening a flagship store here, Apple has a problem that any retailer would envy: the huge 16,000-square-foot space is already too small. Huge crowds descend the store's glass staircase, only to discover legions of mostly young Chinese crowding around spare displays of Apple's devices. Another Apple Store, four miles away, is also packed.
